event: First mention of Lithuania in writing, tied to the murder of St. Bruno by likely pagan Lithuanians.
King Mindaugas's coronation solidified Lithuania, preventing conquest by Crusaders and initiating rapid expansion.
The Union of Krėva brought Lithuanian Christianity and an alliance with Poland, ending crusades against Lithuania.
The Battle of Žalgiris marked Lithuania and Poland's victory over the Teutonic Knights, showcasing Lithuania's medieval power.
Lithuania ceded one-third of its land to Muscovy, starting the enduring 'Russian menace.'
The Union of Lublin united Poland and Lithuania, reducing Lithuania's status but restoring regional strength.
The Deluge devastated Lithuania and Vilnius, marking the decline of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.
The Third Partition of Poland-Lithuania ended the Commonwealth, with most of Lithuania under Russian control.
The Russian Empire's Lithuanian language ban fueled the Lithuanian National Revival.
German occupation during World War I raised Lithuanian hopes for independence.
Lithuania declared independence, restoring sovereignty for the first time since 1569.
Poland's annexation of Vilnius ended the dream of a united Polish-Lithuanian state.
The Klaipėda Revolt reunited Lithuania-proper with Lithuania Minor, securing international recognition.
The Soviet Union occupied Lithuania, initiating genocide and oppression.
Nazi Germany occupied Lithuania, halting Soviet oppression but initiating the Holocaust.
The Soviet re-occupation brought genocide, guerilla resistance, and economic stagnation.
The Baltic Way symbolized Baltic unity against Soviet rule and boosted hopes for independence.
Lithuania became the first Soviet republic to declare independence, accelerating the USSR's collapse.
Lithuanians protected their independence during the January Events, leading to global recognition.
Lithuania joined the European Union, integrating economically and politically but losing population to emigration.
Lithuania joined an international military alliance NATO.
